title: The Bachelor casts 'its first black lead' with Rachel Lindsay from the current season
text:
The Bachelor casts 'its first black lead' with Rachel Lindsay from the current season Sources say the 31-year-old Texas native will be the next Bachelorette Share Rachel is rumoured to be the new Bachelorette (Photo: ABC) Share Get celebs   Thank you for subscribing!   
After 15 years and 21 seasons of The Bachelor and 12 seasons of The Batchelorette, ABC has reportedly cast its first black lead. 
Contestant Rachel Lindsay is said to be starring as the next Bachelorette. 
According to Variety, insiders says the network wanted to wait until after tonight's episode to announce the news, but famed Bachelor blogger Reality Steve leaked the news early. 
The official announcement is said to be coming on Monday night's Jimmy Kimmel Live. 
Lindsay, 31, is an attorney from Dallas, Texas, is currently in the running on Nick Viall's season. Rachel Lindsay of The Bachelorette (Photo: ABC) 
She is currently in the running on Nick Viall's season, which airs Monday nights. 
Typically, the next Bachelor or Bachelorette is one of the fan-favorite runner-ups from the latest pool of contestants. 
The Bachelor franchise has long endured criticism of its lack of diverse casting, especially among the leads. 
While the crop of contestants have become a bit more diverse over the years, for more than 30 seasons of The Bachelor and The Bachelorette, an African-American man or woman has never held the main title. Rachel Lindsay of The Bachelorette (Photo: ABC) Rachel Lindsay of The Bachelorette (Photo: ABC) 
Back in early 2016, former ABC boss Paul Lee teased an upcoming black Bachelorette, telling press members at the Television Critics Association, "We're doing a whole lot of tweaks...We have the farm team, right, which allows us to then pick the next one. But I'd be very surprised if The Bachelorette in the summer isn't diverse. I think that's likely." 
Following his remarks, Jojo Fletcher, who is half Persian and half Caucasian, nabbed the main role for Season 12, causing fans to slam the network's choice on social media, saying Fletcher was not diverse enough. Rachel Lindsay of The Bachelorette (Photo: ABC) Read More Dillon Francisâ€™ X-rated commentary of The Bachelor goes viral as he unleashes hilarious foul-mouthed rant 
This past summer, ABC president Channing Dungey - the first-ever African-American woman to lead a broadcast network - was asked by reporters at TCA about The Bachelor's"diversity problem. 
She said, "I would very much like to see some changes there. I think one of the big changes that we need to do is increase the pool [of contestants] in the beginning." 
The current season of The Bachelor has had the most diverse pool of contestants. 
From Viall's original 30 ladies, eight were non-white, in comparison to five diverse contestants the season before with main man Ben Higgins and just one non-white contestant in Chris Soules' season. Like us on Facebook
